channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed for eurogamer_net

item.title: The Super Mario Galaxy Movie's US release date has been brought forward
item.content:encoded:
The Super Mario Galaxy Movie will now release across all major markets on 1st April, including the US.

Previously, the highly anticipated sequel had been slated to release in the US on 3rd April, but the stateside release date has now been brought forward to align with the movie's debut across Europe, including the UK.

The Japanese release, however, pencilled in for 24th April, has not been moved.

"The Super Mario Galaxy Movie will move from April 3, 2026, to April 1, 2026 in the US and many additional markets globally, and will be released on April 24, 2026, in Japan, with select territories releasing throughout April," Nintendo announced, as spotted by VGC.

Over the weekend, Nintendo unveiled a new trailer showcasing the upcoming Super Mario Galaxy Movie, giving us our first look at the previously-leaked Yoshi and Birdo.

The two-minute preview, which debuted overnight, was introduced by Nintendo's Shigeru Miyamoto, and sees Mario and Luigi pull up to investigate a "troubled pipe". We also get our first peek at Yoshi and Birdo.

As well as the usual gaggle of characters, the upcoming animated sequel will also see Bowser Junior and Rosalina joining the chaos, the latter of which is being voiced by long-time Nintendo fan, Brie Larson.

Animation studio Illumination's first movie adaptation, The Super Mario Bros. Movie, proved to be a huge hit when it released in 2023, grossing over $1bn worldwide.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/the-super-mario-galaxy-movies-us-release-date-has-been-brought-forward

item.title: Resident Evil Survival Unit is getting a new rookie, and she's "headed your way soon"
item.content:encoded:
A familiar face is on its way to Resident Evil Survival Unit, one that will no doubt delight Albert Wesker (if you know, you know): Rebecca Chambers.

Described as "a chemistry expert who flew through university at a young age", the Legendary character Rebecca brings her sharp intellect and specialism to the team, including a raft of exploration and field skills to help you out.

Here's what Rebecca has to offer, with the '?' denoting a value that scales based on the character's level:

Exploration:

  • Lv.?: First Aid Spray: uses a healing medical spray on a single ally, recovering HP equal to ?% of Rebecca's Attack.
  • Lv.?: Molotov Cocktail: Every 20 seconds, lobs a Molotov cocktail. When the Molotov cocktail lands, it sets the area on fire for 10 seconds, dealing damage equal to ?% of Attach per second to any enemies within the area. Enemies affected by the flames are burned, taking damage equal to ?% of Attack per second for five seconds.
  • Lv.?: Herbal Mix: Every 12 seconds, Rebecca mixes herbs, recovering HP equal to ?% of Rebecca's Attack for all allies.

Field:

  • Lv.?: Combat Medical Expertise: Increases the attack of the deployed squad by ?% and Defense by ?%.
  • Lv.?: Stimulant: When deployed Allied squad attacks, there is a 25% chance to deal ?% increased damage.
  • Lv.?: Anesthetic: When deployed Allied squad attacks, there is a 40% chance to take ?% reduced damage.

The team did not confirm specifically when Chambers would be reporting for duty, but she's apparently "headed your way soon".

Capcom reckons Resident Evil: Survival Unit offers "a fresh, mobile-first gameplay experience that diverges from the traditional survival horror format of the main series". It has already been downloaded over a million times.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/resident-evil-survival-unit-is-getting-a-new-rookie-and-shes-headed-your-way-soon

item.title: An unannounced Rayman 30th Anniversary Edition has popped up on the Australian ratings board
item.content:encoded:
An unannounced Rayman 30th Anniversary Edition has popped up on the Australian Classification Board.

The Australian government has rated it a 'G' - the equivalent to the UK's 'U' - for its "very mild impact" violence. It's reportedly coming to both the PS5 and Nintendo Switch, with Atari listed as both the developer and publisher.

Rumour has it Ubisoft is also working on a Rayman Legends remake, although it's now unclear if those plans have been scuppered by Ubisoft's "reset" in which it closed two studios and cancelled six projects, including its much-delayed Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time remake. The news wiped over a third off its share price.

On the 30th anniversary of the Rayman series, towards the end of last year, brand producer Loic Gounon spoke about the history of the series and provided a little teaser of what's to come. In a video posted on the official Rayman X account, which had been dormant for years prior to the announcement, Gounon stated: "A very talented team at Ubisoft Montpellier and Ubisoft Milan are currently working on the future of Rayman. Don't expect news from us too soon, but rest assured, Rayman is in good hands."

To mark the 30th anniversary of Rayman, Gounon also announced Ubisoft will be sharing behind-the-scenes anecdotes, interviews, concept art, and more.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/an-unannounced-rayman-30th-anniversary-edition-has-popped-up-on-the-australian-ratings-board

item.title: Ubisoft's "reset" wipes 34% off its share price, the lowest in 15 years
item.content:encoded:
Ubisoft has wiped over a third off its share price after announcing a "reset" would close down two studios and cancel six games.

As noted by CNBC (thanks, PC Gamer), the stock price had progressively declined since the pandemic, but on Thursday - the day after its announcement - it plummeted another 34 percent. It's the lowest share price the company has had since 2011, when it reported losses in the multi-millions, and closed at just €4.06. Just seven days prior, the share price was €6.89.

Ubisoft closed two studios and cancelled six projects - including its much-delayed Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time remake - last week as part of a major restructuring effort that will also see delays for seven games. Described as a "major organisational, operational and portfolio reset", the publisher/developer said the cuts come as it struggles to compete in a "persistently more selective AAA market and an increasingly competitive shooter landscape".

As well as the six cancellations, Ubisoft has also confirmed it is delaying seven unspecified games "to ensure enhanced quality benchmarks are fully met" and to "maximise long-term value creation". Though not confirmed, it's widely believed that this includes the unannounced but much-rumoured Assassin's Creed Black Flag remake.

All this has led Ubisoft to revise its guidance for the full financial year, saying it now expects net bookings of around €1.5bn - a reduction of €330m.

As Matt reported for us at the time, the restructuring will now see the publisher split its efforts across five "creative houses", respectively focused on "scaling and extending" its biggest properties (including Assassin's Creed, Far Cry, and Rainbow Six); on competitive and cooperative shooter experiences (The Division, Ghost Recon, Splinter Cell); on live experiences (For Honor, The Crew, Riders Republic, Brawlhalla, Skull & Bones); on immersive fantasy worlds and narrative-driven universes (Anno, Might & Magic, Rayman, Prince of Persia, Beyond Good & Evil), and on casual and family games.

Former Assassin's Creed leader Marc-Alexis Côté is reportedly suing Ubisoft following a surprise and suspicious departure from the company last year.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/ubisofts-reset-wipes-34-off-its-share-price-the-lowest-in-15-years
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Dataminers claim Yakuza Kiwami 3's ending has been changed, with a considerable knock-on effect on the rest of the franchise
item.content:encoded:
And it's "massively retconed the end to the point where it retcons something in Yakuza 4", too.

Dataminers believe they've found evidence that Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio has changed the ending to Yakuza 3 in the upcoming Yakuza Kiwami 3.

Though the game isn't even out yet, some dataminers claim to have discovered the full script hidden in the playable demo, suggesting the ending has been revised.

The report that follows contains HUGE spoilers for Yakuza 3, so only proceed if you're happy to be spoiled!

At the end of the original Yakuza 3, the game's main antagonist, Yoshitaka Mine, plummets to his death, taking fellow bad guy Andre Richardson with him, and setting up the events of Yakuza 4. Now, however, if the claims are true, Mine miraculously survives the fall and joins the Daidoji, with a considerable knock-on effect on the rest of the franchise. Dark Ties, a spin-off game bundled in with Yakuza Kiwami 3, is a prequel starring Mine (thanks, TheGamer).

"The ending for Dark Ties has been leaked and has massively retconed the end of the game to the point where it rectons something in Yakuza 4," said one player. Another said they had "definite proof" regarding the amended conclusion, writing: "I was sceptic first, but after having datamined the demo myself with a datamining tool and exploring the auth file (for anyone trying themselves -> par decomp. -> data and db.bis.en-> Auth file), I found the proof for the new end."

Back in September, though, the studio said there "won't be any major changes to the story", but did suggest we'd get to learn more about the motivations behind why certain characters behave the way that they do.

The silver lining, I guess, is that we don't have long to wait to find out if this is just a troll kicking up trouble or that the game's conclusion really has changed: Yakuza Kiwami 3 & Dark Ties is set to release for PC, PS5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, and last-gen consoles on 12th February, 2026.

This latest furore comes on top of pressure from fans to remove Teruyuki Kagawa, who portrays Goh Hamazaki, from the cast after he admitted to sexual misconduct and forcibly touched a woman without consent in 2019.

Last weekend, we learned Yakuza 3 Remastered will no longer be available as a standalone purchase after Yakuza Kiwami 3 & Dark Ties releases next month. While people who already own the game will "still be able to continue playing it", "those new to the series who wish to experience the original version" will only be able to play it if they buy the whole Yakua Complete Series bundle.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/dataminers-claim-yakuza-kiwami-3s-ending-has-been-changed-with-a-considerable-knock-on-effect-on-the-rest-of-the-franchise
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: New Super Mario Galaxy Movie Direct unveils new characters that do not disappoint
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo has unveiled a new trailer showcasing the upcoming Super Mario Galaxy Movie, giving us our first look at Yoshi and, I'm delighted to report, Birdo.

The two-minute preview, which debuted overnight, was introduced by Nintendo's Shigeru Miyamoto, and sees Mario and Luigi - seemingly cosplaying as Dune characters - pull up in the Tostarena Kingdom to address a "troubled pipe". Complete with the score we all know so well, the brothers enter what appears to be an ancient temple and meet a very familiar face.

You can check it out below:

We also get to see Baby Mario and Luigi, Peach, Toad, Birdo, and catch Luigi ribbeting in a Frog Suit.

"After the first trailer was released, people were asking, is Yoshi not going to be in the movie?" Miyamoto explained. "Of course he's in it! For over 30 years, Yoshi has been a significant part of Mario's adventure.

"When we began developing Super Mario World, Yoshi was created from the idea of wanting to run around while on a small dinosaur. Mr. Kondo added percussion to the background music, and Yoshi - who's fun to use for running, jumping, stomping, eating things, and laying eggs - was born.

"Even after evolving into 3D, Yoshi has continued to play an active role across different games."

Illumination's Chris Meledandri also confirmed that animation has now been "fully completed", and the movie has moved into post-production, with teams now focused on music and sound design, which includes a 70-piece orchestra.

Along with Mario and Luigi, the upcoming animated sequel will also see Bowser Junior and Rosalina joining the chaos, the latter of which is being voiced by long-time Nintendo fan, Brie Larson.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/new-super-mario-galaxy-movie-direct-unveils-new-characters-that-do-not-disappoint
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot
